lessons.title: What is JavaScript?
lessons.content: JavaScript is a high-level, dynamic programming language used to make websites interactive. It runs in the browser and on servers using environments like Node.js.

lessons.title: How JavaScript Works
lessons.content: JavaScript runs inside a browser's JS engine (such as V8). It uses a single-threaded event loop, call stack, and Web APIs to manage asynchronous tasks efficiently.

lessons.title: Setup Environment
lessons.content: To start coding in JS, install Node.js, choose a code editor like VS Code, and set up a basic project folder with an index.js file.

lessons.title: Variables
lessons.content: Variables store data values. Use const for non-changing values, let for reassigned values, and avoid var due to function scoping and hoisting issues.

lessons.title: Data Types
lessons.content: JavaScript has primitive types (string, number, boolean, null, undefined, symbol, bigint) and reference types (objects, arrays, functions).

lessons.title: Operators
lessons.content: Operators include arithmetic (+, -, *, /), comparison (===, !=), logical (&&, ||), and assignment (=, +=). They allow calculations and logical decisions.

lessons.title: Conditionals
lessons.content: Conditional statements allow programs to perform different actions based on conditions using if, else if, else, and switch.

lessons.title: Function Basics
lessons.content: Functions are reusable blocks of code. Declare them using function declarations, function expressions, or arrow functions.

lessons.title: Arrow Functions
lessons.content: Arrow functions provide shorter syntax and lexically bind 'this'. Example: const sum = (a, b) => a + b.

lessons.title: Scope & Hoisting
lessons.content: Scope defines where variables can be accessed. Hoisting moves declarations to the top of the scope during compilation.

lessons.title: Selecting Elements
lessons.content: Use querySelector, getElementById, and class selectors to target DOM nodes for manipulation.

lessons.title: Updating Elements
lessons.content: Modify HTML, text, or styling via innerText, innerHTML, and style properties.

lessons.title: Event Listeners
lessons.content: Use addEventListener to respond to user interactions such as clicks, input changes, and keyboard events.

lessons.title: Callbacks
lessons.content: Callbacks are functions passed as arguments to other functions, mainly used for async operations. They can lead to callback hell.

lessons.title: Promises
lessons.content: Promises represent the result of an async operation. They have states: pending, fulfilled, rejected.

lessons.title: Async/Await
lessons.content: Async/await provides cleaner asynchronous code using try/catch for error handling.

lessons.title: Template Literals
lessons.content: Template literals allow easier string formatting using backticks and ${expressions}.

lessons.title: Destructuring
lessons.content: Destructuring extracts values from arrays and objects into variables easily.

lessons.title: Spread & Rest Operators
lessons.content: Spread (...) expands values, while rest (...) collects remaining items into an array.

lessons.title: Classes & Constructors
lessons.content: Classes create reusable object blueprints using constructor methods and properties.

lessons.title: Inheritance
lessons.content: Inheritance allows child classes to access parent class features using extends and super().
